"So in summary, a scientific fact is an observable natural occurrence; a scientific theory is an attempt to explain how this natural occurrence works; and, a scientific law is a mathematical description of this natural occurrence."
 
 http://emporium.turnpike.net/C/cs/theory.htm

post_info.post_title: Definition of Scientific fact, theory, and law

Some people have been having trouble with definitions around here.
Oh I know all to well, don't get me started.

Pikeman
 Tell me why "science" does not want to touch the "a priori" questions? So much so that in its dogmatic bigotry some philosophers even try to say that the "origin" questions are out
 of the "domain of science". That is a nonsense. The "beginnings"
 must be the determining questions of all real science.

Tell me why "science" does not want to touch the "a priori" questions? So much so that in its dogmatic bigotry some philosophers even try to say that the "origin" questions are out of the "domain of science". That is a nonsense. The "beginnings"
 must be the determining questions of all real science.

 Where did you ever hear that? I think you are confused. You have certainly shown that you are confused about evolution. What "origins" are you talking about? There are all kinds of sciences that deal with the origins of things. Cosmology is the science that deals with the origin of the universe. There are planetary physicists who deal with the origin of planetary systems. Abiogenesis studies how life on earth arose. But since all of these are science, they are also naturalistic. Perhaps if you were more specific about what a priori question you mean and how they should be studied by science.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Definition of Scientific fact, theory, and law
